Senior Executive Staff via email: cap-bcp-exec-notification@cisco.com,

Include CAP contacts on the email including, link to the CAP DM Page, cap-americas, cap-emea, cap-asia and ce-cpr-team.

CE Teams Manage all new and existing requests
The CAP/EE IM manager will use telephone, email, etc. to manage the case
Create email report using Outlook / manage actions manually
EE IM will refer to the latest weekly EE IM Summary Email to find a list of all open cases use this data to continue work on all open cases. Event DM Should facilitate the hand-off of EE Cases to alternative resolution leaders in the event of a team member not available.
For EEIM catastrophic outages cases, to send reports when CLIP is down, use the email template available in the EmailTemplate - CatOut and EmailTemplate - Executive Escalation in the Team Resources Sharepoint
Use a recent CAP report email as a template for outgoing CAP reports
Create team Mailer aliases if required
CPR will temporally record cases using the SharePoint Case Tracker and manual reports to keep notes on cases.

CIC Guidelines

CIC DM Reference folder also contains a list of report templates and BCP instructions in the IC Checklist.



Ordering and Funding product and services Ordering Cisco Product
Details of ordering Cisco product for CAP cases are on CAP Knowledge, Parts-Services-Ordering section FAQ for Customer Service Ordering. 

When CLIP is unavailable to order urgent Cisco products, follow the below steps:
Send an email to cs-cap@cisco.com to create a PO (CAPnnnnnn) and SO number for the CAP order.  Start the Subject line of the email with "ACTION: CS CAP.”  You will need the following pieces of information:
CID: Customer ship to contact, address, and telephone number information
BID: Bill to contact, address, and telephone number information
Importer of Record contact, address, and telephone number information
BOM (CCW Config ID and CCW Access Key) or PID details
If email is unavailable, contact the CS escalation team at (US) +1-800-553-6387, opt.2, opt. 7 (escalations) and ask to speak to the CAP CS lead on duty.  

After Customer Service has entered the order, send an email to cap-funding-notify@cisco.com and cap-wty-funding@cisco.com  and provide the following information:
CAP Case #
Product Family Impacted and percentage breakdown
Responsibility (% breakdown by organisations)
PO and SO numbers
BOM (CCW Config ID and CCW Access Key) or PID details
List price if available
If email is unavailable, contact Robyn Merck (US +1 919-392-9338), Sarah Fink (US +1 919-392-0626) or Bill Ridge (AU +61 2 8446 6808)
CX - Ordering and Funding product and services 
Details of ordering CX Professional Services to assist with a CAP case are on CAP Knowledge, Collaboration section CX Professional Services.  

When CLIP is unavailable to submit an CX funding request, follow the below steps:
Determine the scope of the CX engagement and work with the CX manager or project lead to document; including quoted cost, estimated labour time and hourly cost, and travel.
Request CX manager or project lead to create a PID
Send an email to cap-funding-notify@cisco.com and cap-wty-funding@cisco.com of the CX PID and the below information:
Title – Especially important for CX, as we have to keep straight CX/HTTS/HTE/HTOM etc.
CAP Case #
PID
Product family impacted and percentage breakdown
Responsibility (% breakdown by organization)
Quoted Cost
And then any information to support quoted cost (SOW, breakdown of hour x rate + travel, etc.)
If email is unavailable, contact Robyn Merck (US +1 919-392-9338), Sarah Fink (US +1 919-392-0626) or Bill Ridge (AU +61 2 8446 6808)

Third Party Vendor - Ordering and Funding product and services
Details of ordering product and services for a CAP case on CAP Knowledge, see Ordering section and Ordering Partner or Outside Services, respectively.

When CLIP is unavailable to submit a third-party funding request, follow the below steps: 
Working through iProcurement, create a Purchase Requisition (PR) number and receive a Purchase Order (PO) number from the vendor
Once the PR and PO are available, send email to cap-funding-notify@cisco.com and cap-wty-funding@cisco.com with the following information.
Provide the following information:
Title of the request
CAP case number
Product family impacted and percentage breakdown
Responsibility (% breakdown by organization)
Purchase Requisition (PR) number
Purchase Order (PO) number 
CAP Dept Code or Billing Account number
Quoted cost
Copy of SOW
If email is not available, contact Robyn Merck (US +1 919-392-9338), Sarah Fink (US +1 919-392-0626) or Bill Ridge (AU +61 2 8446 6808).

content.title: The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.
steps: The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.
There are a few terms mentioned in the document that are worth highlighting and defined as follows:
BFT: Business Function Team (Primary Contacts to be Alerted)
DM:  On-call Duty Manager
RTO: Recovery Time Objective

content.title: Roles and Responsibilities
steps: The On-call CPR Lead identifies whether a Business Continuity (BC) incident should be reported to the Business Function Team (BFT).
The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an Event Manager (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.

content.title: Contact and Convene the BFT
steps: CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT (ce-bft-epage) to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a WebEx meeting (if available): https://cisco.webex.com/cisco
If Webex is not available, the following Everbridge Dial-In-Bridge can be activated:
Hosting a call:
To invite participants to your conference call, provide them with the Everbridge Dial-In Number and the Conference ID and passcode number:
Dial-In Number
Conference ID #: Passcode
If Everbridge Dial-In Bridge cannot be activated, CPR Lead uses mobile phone to organize BFT briefing with appropriate and available BFT Members

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan

Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.

content.title: In case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.
steps:
Execute the BFT Action Plan

Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
CPR Lead assumes responsibility.
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implement the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations

Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful

content.name: Sustainable Timeframe:

content.role:
Shift workload to other CMS regions where possible.

Transition Workload 
Working from home may not be feasible in all situations. If CX CMS is unable to operate at normal productivity levels by working at home, then the BFT/Event Duty Manager may decide to offload work to the shift before and the shift after the affected site. 
To get that help, the Command Center Duty Manager works with the Local Site Contacts, and the BFT Managers to allocate the workload to non-impacted sites. • Identify dependencies on potential site 
• Identify additional workload on potential site 
• Coordinate transition with appropriate teams and management 

Relocate Personnel to Alternate Site 
If a CX CMS site is unavailable for an extended period, the BFT will decide alternatives, such as temporarily working in another building or moving to a different site until the original site is accessible again. The Site Manager will communicate the instructions and timing of moving to a different building or site location once that location becomes available. 
• Identify Site 
• Coordinate Relocation Requirements 
• Inform Employees of Site Move and Schedule

steps: Appendix B
Emergency Customer Communication Templates

These templates have been provided for quick reference when it is necessary to alert customers to emergency situations that prevent or severely limit service delivery. The templates provided have been approved by Corporate Communications for use during emergent situations.

Instructions for use: The BFT should discuss if customer communications are necessary with current or expected circumstances, and nominate one individual to prepare and modify these templates for distribution to customers. Existing CMS tools may provide a method of managing these email communications.
Three templates are provided:
Temporary Impact to CMS Support
Temporary Impact to CMS Communications

content.title: Temporary Impact to CMS Support
steps: Subject: Important Notice: Temporary Impact to CMS Support
Dear Customer,

CMS is experiencing an issue with our [internal tools/network access to your network/remote access to your network] and as a result, this may impact our ability to provide service for your account. Our teams are actively working to address the situation and will keep you updated on any significant changes.

We appreciate your understanding and patience during this period. If you have any urgent issues, please don't hesitate to contact your Services Manager, who will do their best to connect you with the support you need.
Thank you for your continued support and cooperation.
Best regards,
[Your Name]

content.title: Temporary Impact to CMS Communications
steps: Subject: Important Notice: Temporary Impact to CMS Communications
Dear Customer,

content.title: CMS is experiencing an issue with our [phone/email/ebonding] services and as a result, this may impact our ability to [respond to calls/respond to email requests/process ebonded requests]. Our teams are actively working to address the situation and will keep you updated on any significant changes.
steps: We appreciate your understanding and patience during this period. If you have any urgent issues, please don't hesitate to contact your Services Manager, who will do their best to connect you with the support you need.
Thank you for your continued support and cooperation.
Best regards,
[Your Name]

content.title: Subject: Important Notice: Temporary Impact to CMS Response Times
steps: Dear Customer,

steps: We appreciate your understanding and patience during this period. If you have any critical issues or outages, please don't hesitate to contact your Services Manager, who will do their best to connect you with the support you need.
Thank you for your continued support and cooperation.
Best regards,
[Your Name]

No workarounds available.

Strategy Description: Re-route cases

Workaround: Rules based on which service requests get routed in CSOne.
All cases are assigned to the ‘BCP-GLOBAL’ resource group. Basic Technology/Sub-Technology/Problem Code (T/ST/PC) routing allows cases to be accepted from the ‘BCP-GLOBAL’ queue when the BRE is down, but the rest of CSOne is up
Backlog Processing/Return to Normal: All BCP indicators are removed once the BRE is back up. Regular case routing resumes

content.title: A business interruption is defined as any event (anticipated or unanticipated) that disrupts normal business operations. A disaster is defined as a sudden, unplanned catastrophic event compromising an organization’s ability to provide critical business processes or services for an unacceptable period.
steps: Subtopics:
1. Scope
2. How to use the BCP
3. Quick Activation and Engagement Guide
4. When to Activate the BCP
5. Recovery Teams

content.title: 7. Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes
steps: 8. Recovery Strategies
9. Other Dependencies
10. Appendix A
1. Scope
Scope

content.title: The plan scope is limited to the business function identified on the cover page only. The plan scope does not include emergency management. The list of business processes covered in this plan can be found on the “Business Process Scope and Recovery Timeframes (RTO)” table.
steps: 2. How to use the BCP
How to use the BCP

content.title: The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.
steps: The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.
3. Quick Activation and Engagement Guide
Quick Activation and Engagement Guide

content.title: Step 3: Category = Impact Assessment: Does the incident impact any business processes (page 7)?
steps: If yes; CPR to review the Pre-Escalation Action Plan to determine impact to the business and proceeds to next step.
If no; activation is not required.
Review approximate number of impacted employees – CX Centers BCP Dashboard
Step 4: Category = Engage Recovery Teams: CPR engages the recovery teams

Step 5: Category = BFT to Assess Situation: Once the recovery team(s) are convened, the CPR Team and BFT need to review the BFT Discussion Points (12) and determine if the Business Continuity Plan should be activated.
Step 6: Category = BFT Action Plan: Once the recovery team(s) have formed a continuity plan for execution, the CPR team will continue to assist the BFT by executing the BFT Action Plan (page 13).
Step 7: Category = Execute Workarounds: Implement the appropriate business continuity strategy in section VI.

Step 8: Category = Crisis Communication: CPR Team emails the Initial Situation Report (page 13) at the conclusion of the initial BFT call. CPR emails On-going Situation Reports (page 13) every two hours or as appropriate.

Step 9: Category = Return to Normal Operations: When the situation returns to normal, the CPR engages the recovery teams (page 8) to determine closing out the business continuity activation. If the recovery team(s) agrees to end the activation, the CPR will communicate the Return to Normal Operations (page 13).
Step 10: Category = After Action Documentation: Complete the post-activation report and return to onex-bcp-team mailer.
4. When to Activate the BCP
When to Activate the BCP

content.title: Using judgement, key stakeholders should determine if the business interruption is severe enough and where it will exceed business-defined recovery time objectives (RTO) to activate the Business Continuity Plan (see next page for in scope processes and the respective RTO).
steps: Other criteria to consider when activating a BCP include:
Geographic Impact: Entire Region / Multiple Regions / Global
Business Units Impacted: Multiple / Corporate-wide
Financial Impact: >$10M
Customer Impact: High
Legal Impact Mandated restricted hours, closure of businesses and schools, or National Guard called to assist local authority

content.title: Business Operations Impact: Inability to execute critical elements to maintain acceptable service levels / process failure
steps: Reputational Impact: Regional, National, or International
Employee Impact: Employees requiring hospitalization or employees with critical injuries/death
Absenteeism: >25%
5. Recovery Teams

content.title: Recovery Teams Procedures
steps: Crisis Communications
This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.
Roles and Responsibilities
LOB DM/TL reports a BC incident to the CPR team.
The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an CPR Team (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Pre-Escalation Action Items
After a business continuity incident has occurred, CPR should review the following checklist before contacting the BFT for escalation:
General
How were you made aware of the incident? If an employee reported the incident, what is the person’s name/role within Cisco?
When did the incident occur?
What is the scope of the incident?
Has the Corporate Security Center (CSC) been called?
Validate approximate number of Impacted Personnel using the CXC BCP Dashboard
Operations
What is the impact to Cisco operations? What is the expected duration of the impact on Cisco operations?

content.title: Are business processes interrupted or running at a reduced capacity? If so, to what extent are they affected?
steps: Were any customers or clients impacted?
Buildings/Facility
How many buildings/locations were impacted and where?
Is there physical damage and where?
Can employees still access the building(s) that are affected?
Technology
What technology is affected (infrastructure and/or applications)?
Suppliers/Partners
Are there any critical suppliers that are impacted by the incident, and have they activated their BC/DR plans? If so, notify these suppliers.
BFT Discussion Point:
Employee Safety
Assess the event and overall impact on personal safety
Are your direct reports safe?
Alert the Corporate Security Center (CSC) if the event presents a life safety issue

content.title: General Response
steps: Is there a need for a physical command center location (i.e., a conference room in case of technology/telecommunication unavailability)
Set a schedule for follow-up meetings and communications

content.title: Determine a response and the next steps, including which workarounds should be implemented
steps: Operations
Should any BCP(s) be activated? Which plans?
Are customers impacted? Is there a need to prioritize customers?
Assess the severity and duration of a business function interruption
Identify and obtain any additional resources that are needed to restore critical business functions
Suppliers/Partners
Are Vendors affected? (Determine which function Vendor Managers should join the bridge)
Have any critical suppliers activated their BC and/or DR plans?
Are there alternate supplier/supplier locations that could be used during the incident to maintain continuity of Cisco business activities?
Technology
Is IT troubleshooting the affected technology or has a decision been made to recover the technology at an alternate location? Which technology is affected?
What is the ETA for availability of technology? Which technology?
Contact and Convene the BFT
The DM should contact the CPR team to begin crisis communications via an incident report on CLIP. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a Webex meeting (if available)
Full Webex Teams outage: CPR creates and joins the bridge Epages the SL using the chart below to join the Webex bridge(s)
If Webex is not available, please contact the CPR Team to coordinate an interim solution.
Form the BFT Command Center and Action Plan
Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via Webex and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.

content.title: In the case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.
steps:
Execute the BFT Action Plan
Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Assign a CPR Team (EM) to manage the business interruption (as necessary)
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implementing the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations
Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful

content.title: The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.
steps: The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.

content.title: Using judgement, key stakeholders should determine if the business interruption is severe enough where it will exceed business-defined recovery time objectives (RTO) to activate the Business Continuity Plan (see next page for in scope processes and the respective RTO).

content.role:
Do you have an ESP ticket already created over phone +1 408 526-8888 or in the ServiceNow?

If Yes: 
Has the ticket already been escalated?
If Yes, Go to Step B3.
If No, escalate it by clicking Request Escalation button shown in the right column of the case. Include Reason for Escalation and Escalation Details and then press Save button. Go to Step B3.
If No, open a new case at ServiceNow.

 NOTE: In HelpZone, users are provided with two options for engaging IT services:

Submit A Case: (Incidents) This option is for Break/Fix related support only. That is, something that was previously working and is no longer functioning.
Request Forms (Tab): (Requests) These options are for production items that need to be created, modified, or deleted.
 
For a detailed breakdown of when to use which type of Contact Center Request Form, please see our Contact Center Client Wiki:

content.title: Purpose
steps: This Business Continuity Plan (BCP) applies to the continuance of the functional areas belonging to the Logistic Support Center (LSC) team in APAC, US, EMEA and JAPAN.

content.title: In Scope
steps: Voice, Premium order and Proactive monitoring support for US, EMEA & APAC, except those in the “Out of Scope” section

content.title: Out of Scope
steps: This BCP currently does not cover LSC services for Email, Chat services and Standard Orders support.

content.title: Global Resource Allocation
steps: There are approximately 111 Logistics Support Center (LSC) agents globally. For a breakdown of this support, refer to the following table:

content.title: Services Offered
steps: The Logistics Support Center (LSC) is organized to offer the following services:
Global Service Relation Call: Handle all calls related to RMA entitlement based on follow-the-sun model (applies for APAC, EMEA and US).
Theatre Voice Calls: Handles all calls related to RMA support.
OMC: Manage all email cases related to RMA support.
Chat service: Manage chat services for all customer/partners who require assistance for PRR tool  (available for all theaters)
Order Dispatch: Manage premium and proactive monitoring of order dispatch via. follow-the-sun model. Standard order is supported and dispatched by local theatres by local cut-off timing.
Refer to http://www.timeanddate.com/time/dst for the exact date period for summer (DST) and Winter (no DST) version.

During the interim period, when not all theaters are aligned with time changes, please use http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/ to determine the local time of a specific country, or http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/converter.html to convert time between different countries

content.title: Network Connectivity:
steps: Business continuity for LSC is primarily dependent on the network connectivity and supporting infrastructure located at each site.  Network connectivity impacts the ability to deliver services via phone, email and chat and can impact the availability of tools needed to support customers.
In the event of a loss of connectivity, agents would move to a different site (or home) and use VPN to access Cisco Systems and tools.

content.title: Geographical or Political Risks:
steps: Each site has its own geographic or political risks, based on previous experiences.
Costa Rica, India: hurricanes/cyclones
Bulgaria: minor snowstorms, minor earthquakes
Malaysia: Haze, epidemic situation such as SARS
Japan: Earthquakes

content.title: OM Event Manager
steps: By default, the OM Event Manager will assume the lead in executing the business continuity plan.
Assesses the event and overall impact to operations and personal safety.
Assesses the severity and duration of a business function interruption.

content.title: Determines the appropriate response.
steps: The following is the list of OM event managers for their respective theatres.

content.title: Criteria for Activation
steps: Identify scenario and assess the extent and timeframe of the service(s) impact
Assess that the impacted service(s) is unable to be restored within the acceptable timeframe
Voice > ~1 hour
Premium SORT Orders and Proactive Monitoring> 30 mins
(Engage via mailer for SORT ESCs – sysops-case-escalation (mailer list) <sysops-case-escalation@cisco.com>)
Validate that vendor troubleshooting has been performed to identify root cause of the issue

If issue identified to be related to Cisco, SYSOPS case must already be opened via HelpZone. https://cisco.service-now.com/helpzone
* Unless no internet connection available

content.title: If this is a P1/P2 case for EMEA, follow S&L – OnProcess – Technical Escalation, FRED and On-Call Support Service EDCS 11642648 (Section B: External Escalation Procedure - Fast Response Escalation Desk (FRED), page 4) to get the right level of attention from IT team to drive case till resolution
steps: Americas – Engage TAC DM for assistance – If you encounter what you feel is a Sev1 or Sev2 priority issue; contact the TAC Duty Manager on shift, explain the situation and the TAC DM will help decide if FRED needs to be activated.
FRED Instructions for TAC DM : http://www-tac.cisco.com/Teams/Duty_Manager/IT_GTRC_Escalation.htm

content.title: Activation of FRED
steps: In the event of major outage, connectivity, or application issues which impact Cisco Contact Centers, Tech Support Escalation team (a.k.a. FRED) will act as a dedicated escalation desk for high impact escalations.  A high impact issue would be something that has a major impact to Cisco Services, Cisco customers or has a finance impacts (i.e.: network, voice, B2B or application outage of an entire contact center or theater).

content.title: LSC Guidelines
steps: For voice support, after call has been routed to supporting theatre LSC team:
Do note that voice service will only be provided in English.

content.title:
Only if customer insists on local language support, leverage on Translation Service Support to facilitate a 3-way call (LSC, customer and translator). 
As this is 3-way call, the call duration tends to be longer, therefore, please set expectation with customer upfront. 

More information on how to use this service can be found at Global Interpretation Services Procedure (EDCS-11733123)
steps:
Languages supported by Global LSC team (Arabic, Czech, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Mandarin, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Thai, Turkish) is available through Translation service.

If LSC do not know language to request, inform Translation Service representative to assist with the request

content.title:
Scenario 1: Activate Call Routing to another Theatre

OM Event Manager dials in to call routing tool at 89932583, and keys in 4 digits pin code (7723) followed by #.  Dial +1 919 9932583 if using an external phone.

Step 1: Select Outage theatre (1 Concentrix, 2 OnProcess Technology, 3 SCSK)
Step 2: Select Alternate theatre (refer to Supporting theatre. Ensure outage theatre obtains buy-in from supporting theatre OM Event Manager before activation) (1 Concentrix, 2 OnProcess Technology, 3 SCSK)
steps: An email will be sent to cc_telephony_bcp@cisco.com to inform on the call routing activation. Conduct test calls to ensure customer call is properly routed to supporting theatre.
Scenario 2: Activate Call Routing to a Different Phone Number
– Take the script that is currently in place and point to the new number
– If unable to re-route script currently in place, CCAT engineer will need to build a new script to be able to route to a different phone number
– Take the script that is currently in place and point to the new number

content.title: OM Event Manager will setup a call bridge with all appropriate parties (following normal WebEx meeting procedures) and prepare to meet with OM BCP team with available info about:
steps: Cause of the business interruption.
Summary of any personal injuries, damage to buildings, infrastructure and equipment.
What business functions have been affected and to what extent.

content.title: Recommendation to invoke Theatre and/or Global BCP process.
steps: OM Duty Manager/ Event Manager sends Duty Manager Notification to inform all relevant stakeholders of BCP event progress and to list who the POC is for engagement in the DM notification.
Impacted theatre OM Event Manager/ Duty Manager to keep in contact with supporting theatre Event Manager every hour to review situation progress.
Scenario 3: De-activate Call Routing (if scenario 1 was activated)
OM Event Manager dial in to call routing tool at 89932583, and key in 4-digit pin code (7723) followed by#.
Dial +1 919 9932583 If using external phone.
Step 1 : OM Event Manager dial in to call routing tool at 89932583, and key in 4-digit pin code (7723) followed by #. Dial +1 919 9932583 If using external phone.
Step 2 : Select option 5 (turn off call routing)
Step 3 : An email will be sent to cc_telephony_bcp@cisco.com to inform call routing de-activation. Conduct test calls to ensure call routing is switched off.
Step 4 : Once the situation is resolved, OM Event Manager informs OM DM to send final restoration of service communication and resume normal business state.
Note: In the event call routing is activated, impacted theatre Event Manager to login to utility tool to turn off disaster recovery routing and conduct test calls.
Note:

If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.

content.title: The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.
steps: The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.

content.title: Using judgement, key stakeholders should determine if the business interruption is severe enough where it will exceed business-defined recovery time objectives (RTO) to activate the Business Continuity Plan (see next page for in scope processes and the respective RTO).
steps: Other criteria to consider when activating a BCP include:

content.title: SECTION III: Recovery Teams
steps: On-Call CPR Team
CPR Team Incident Open and Epage (CLIP link; if NaaS or CLIP unavailable, go to step 2)
CXC CPR Team On-Call (VPN needed, if unavailable CPR contact information is listed with the BFT)

content.title: Business Function Team (BFT)
steps:
The BFT coordinates all continuity activities and controls the implementation of the plan.
ePage: cxc-ps-globalbft

content.title: Crisis Communications
steps: This section is designed for use by the CPR, BFT members and their delegates, or other key stakeholders to determine if the severity of the incident warrants a Business Continuity Plan activation.

content.title: Roles and Responsibilities
steps: The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an Event Manager (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.
Contact and Convene the BFT
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a WebEx meeting (if available): https://cisco.webex.com/cisco
Full Webex Teams outage:  CPR creates and joins the bridge Epages the SL using the chart below to join the Webex bridge(s)
If Webex is not available, please contact the CPR team to coordinate an interim solution.
The following additional resource(s) can be used to convene the BFT:
ePage: cxc-ps-globalbft

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan

Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.

content.title: In case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.
steps:
Execute the BFT Action Plan

Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Assign an Event Manager (EM) to manage the business interruption (as necessary)
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implement the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations

Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful

steps:

Recovery Scenarios and Processes

Fill out the section below for all potential scenarios (4 examples below) for which your Business Process can be impacted. Separate into different sections for scenarios where remediation steps are not the same.
steps: Scenario Types:
Natural Disaster (Earthquake, Tornado, Flooding, anything applicable to your geographical location, etc.)
Technological (Network outage, DNS outage, communications outage, critical application outage etc.)
Human/Community Impact (Pandemic, War, etc.)

content.title: Cyber Attack (Critical application hacked for your business process and data stolen)
steps: Summary of incident: Incidents can vary and range from personnel, technology, natural disasters, cyber-attacks, etc.

content.title: Technologies utilized for the remediation process: Standard Cisco applications and along with several other apps with their respective recovery strategies listed above.
steps: Personnel Skills Required: Staffing managers, engineers, delivery manager, leaders, etc.
Post remediation monitoring: Any offline or manual work should be reconciled as appropriate. Continue to monitor for any further potential issues that may arise.

content.title: The BCP applies when a business interruption/disaster directly or indirectly decreases the capacity of our critical business processes which impacts Cisco’s ability to deliver services to our customers. Depending on the impact of the incident, some parts of the plan may not apply.
steps: The BCP is used by key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts of their specific function. The plan is a guide for key decision makers to coordinate recovery efforts by facilitating communication, creating an action plan, executing workaround strategies, and returning to normal operations.

content.title: Roles and Responsibilities
steps: The DM identifies whether a BC incident should be reported to the CPR team.
The CPR team determines the point person for handling a BC incident, unless this is delegated to an Event Manager (EM).
If a BCP activation is warranted, the CPR team  should use the “Pre-Escalation Action Items” checklist below to initiate crisis communication with the BFT.

Contact and Convene the BFT

Once the DM has determined the incident must be escalated i.e the DM should contact the CPR team.
CPR team will assess the impact and pages out the BFT to begin crisis communication. As members of the BFT are contacted, they will be requested to:
Start or join a WebEx meeting (if available): https://cisco.webex.com/cisco
Full Webex Teams outage:  CPR creates and joins the bridge Epages the SL using the chart below to join the Webex bridge(s)
If Webex is not available, please contact the CPR team to coordinate an interim solution.CPR On- Call

Form a BFT Command Center and Action Plan

Once BFT members have been contacted to form a command center via WebEx and/or other bridge line, the following items should be discussed to initiate crisis communications and resume operations.

content.title: In case of a pandemic alert (WHO Phase 4+), the Cisco Global Pandemic Coordinator will convene BC teams for pandemic monitoring and response.
steps:
Execute the BFT Action Plan

Once the BFT has determined a BCP activation is required, execute the following:
Assign an Event Manager (EM) to manage the business interruption (as necessary)
Assign personnel as needed
Communicate with vendors as required
Act as a decision maker in the allocation of resources during the plan execution period
Keep the BFT informed as necessary and recommend a course of action
Ensure all continuity tasks are appropriately executed
Implement the appropriate business continuity strategies

Return to Normal Operations

Once the BFT has determined the BCP can be deactivated, execute the following:
Identify and coordinate requirements to transition back to normal operations
Ensure business function restoration is successful
